content:
@Niako:

I've added the following new test cases to your puzzle:
* Size 7
* Validator 2
* Size 10
* Validator 4
* Size 11
* Validator 5
* Size 99 (4)
* Validator 12

I've done so after observing that certain published solutions (I've checked Python only), while passing your original set of test cases, fail under additional scenarios.

I apologise for not seeking your prior consent before implementing these changes. The intention is solely to enhance the puzzle's robustness.

Thank you for your understanding.
Added "write maximum number of rooks" to stub generator.
Finally got it solved. The algorithm is abstract to digest but easy to implement

Tried a pure logical deduction approach but my answers are a bit off from your answers in 99 size. Cannot validate it yet. Perhaps I need a mixture of deduction and brute-force to crack it.
Hard puzzles are hard to get passed nowadays with the one-month limit. For me, It is not uncommon to spend a few months to solve one interesting but difficult puzzle.

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

Is this problem too hard or something? It however involves a useful reduction to solve a certain kind of combinatorial optimization problems (and more common that it may seem). This is for instance a minimal prerequisite to solve the harder Google Code Jam 2017 qualification problem D (Fashion Show) or 2018 round 2 problem C (Costume Change).
"must be separated by an occupied square" could be also "must be separated by one or more occupied squares"

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)
Right. Changed it to "at least one". Thanks!

Do  you have any lecture involving the reduction you mentioned ? I would be really interested to understand how they come to it + I guess this may be a very interesting topic to read about for algorithm culture.

There is a nice and neat polynomial-time approach, that's why this kind of problem is interesting ;-) (as it might look like some NP-complete constraint solving problem, but it's not). Deduction+backtracking/brute-force approaches probably won't pass within the time limit. Think about different ways to see the problem and try to reduce it to something else (involving graphs).

I didn't know any lecture on the subject, but it's a recurring topic in competitive programming problems. After a little search, check out this lecture for instance: https://www.math.ust.hk/~mabfchen/Math3343/Matchings.pdf (pb 1, ex 1.1).

Thanks for your answer ! These were some definition/rules I have not heard of before but after reading the appropriate resources (and your link) and applying the known algorithm, I understood why you used the reduction you mentionned :) Great subject

There is a lack of approvals these times ?
Personaly, I don't have the required level yet ...

I don't know exactly, I've submitted 3 problems, an easy one that was accepted in less than a week and 2 hard ones that are pending for almost 3 months. I guess hard problems have a hard time making it through as they require more attention and time from the testers.
